responses.rationale: The segment describes a factual event (first death) without using high-potency verbs or metaphors.
The segment uses moderate language ('affect humans in rare cases') without high-potency verbs or metaphors.
The segment factually describes actions taken ('prevention zone was declared', 'strict biosecurity measures', 'flock... was culled') without high-potency language.
The segment factually describes a sequence of events ('followed a similar move') without high-potency language.

The segment describes actions and findings ('put the country on increased risk', 'ordering poultry to be kept indoors', 'highly pathogenic variant was identified') using factual language, not high-potency verbs or metaphors. 'Highly pathogenic' is a technical term.
The segment factually describes how the virus circulates and spreads ('circulates naturally', 'can be spread') without high-potency language.
The segment factually reports an outbreak ('reported an H5N1 bird flu outbreak') without high-potency language.
The segment factually describes the virus serotype ('serotype in this outbreak was H5N8') without high-potency language.
The segment factually reports an outbreak ('reported its first outbreak') without high-potency language.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'slaughtered' to describe the outcome for the animals.
The segment factually reports an outbreak ('reported an outbreak') without high-potency language.
The segment factually reports human infections ('reported 21 human infections') without high-potency language.
The segment describes attention and transmission ('attracting the attention', 'virus can be transmitted') using factual language.
The segment uses the critical alert phrase 'put the poultry industry on alert', which is listed as an Alarmist cue.

The segment reports outbreaks and spread ('Several outbreaks... have been reported', 'virus is spreading quickly again') using descriptive but not high-potency language. 'Spreading' is a moderate verb.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'slaughtered' to describe the outcome for the animals.

The segment describes actions and findings ('start vaccinating', 'highly contagious H5N1 strain was first detected') using factual language. 'Highly contagious' is descriptive but not a high-potency verb or metaphor.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'slaughtered' to describe the outcome for the birds.
The segment factually describes how the disease is carried and transmitted ('disease is often carried', 'can then transmit') without high-potency language.
The segment factually reports deaths ('killed 200 pelicans') without using a high-potency verb or metaphor.
The segment reports an outbreak and spread ('reported its first outbreak', 'disease swept through') using factual language. 'Swept through' is a moderate verb according to the boundary guard.
The segment is a question without high-potency language.
The segment introduces safety recommendations without high-potency language.
The segment describes an investigation and potential changes ('investigating whether the genetic sequence... has changed', 'show signs of increasing transmissibility') using factual language.
The segment describes potential future events ('could also evolve', 'could trigger a pandemic') without using high-potency verbs or metaphors to describe current impact.
The segment states risk levels and potential severity ('does not pose a significant risk', 'potential to cause severe disease') using factual assessments, not high-potency language.
The segment states a risk level ('does not pose a significant risk') using factual assessment, not high-potency language.
The segment factually describes symptoms ('symptoms... have been mild') without high-potency language.
The segment factually describes the location and contact of cases ('all those infected were working', 'had direct contact') without high-potency language.
The segment assesses risk levels ('are at most risk', 'risk of illness... is still negligible') using factual language.
The segment states the rarity of infection ('It is rare for avian influenza to infect humans') using factual language.
The segment factually describes the location of cases ('latest cases... were among poultry workers') without high-potency language.
The segment describes an outbreak and confirmed cases ('A "multi-state outbreak"... has emerged', 'four human cases have been confirmed') using factual language. 'Emerged' is a moderate verb.
The segment describes transmission ('can sometimes jump into animals') using factual language.
The segment defines the illness and how it spreads ('is an infectious viral illness that spreads primarily') using factual language. 'Highly pathogenic' is a technical term.
The segment factually reports cases ('confirmed a fourth human bird flu case') without high-potency language.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'slaughter' to describe the outcome for the animals.
The segment factually reports an outbreak ('reported a new outbreak') without high-potency language. 'Highly pathogenic' is a technical term.
The segment factually reports infections ('reported infections') without high-potency language.
The segment provides a status update ('Full results... are pending') without high-potency language.
The segment factually reports test results ('Tests... were inconclusive', 'samples... tested positive') without high-potency language.

The segment reports an infection ('A fourth farm worker has been infected') and describes the outbreak ('in the growing outbreak') using factual language. 'Growing' is descriptive but not high-potency.
The segment assesses risk ('are at higher risk of infection') using factual language.
The segment reports surveillance findings ('have shown no unusual activity') using factual language.

The segment reports an infection ('A fourth farm worker has been infected') and describes the outbreak ('in the growing outbreak') using factual language. 'Growing' is descriptive but not high-potency. The statement about low risk is Q5 territory.
The segment factually reports a case ('first U.S. case... was detected') without high-potency language.
The segment factually reports cases and symptoms ('Three previous cases... have been reported', 'developed pink eye', 'had mild respiratory symptoms') without high-potency language.
The segment factually reports cases ('Three previous cases... have been reported') without high-potency language.
The segment factually describes contact and symptoms ('had direct contact', 'developed pink eye', 'has recovered') without high-potency language.

The segment reports an infection ('A fourth farm worker has been infected') and describes the outbreak ('in the growing outbreak') using factual language. 'Growing' is descriptive but not high-potency.

The segment reports an infection ('A fourth farm worker has been infected') and describes the outbreak ('in the growing outbreak') using factual language. 'Growing' is descriptive but not high-potency.
The segment describes securing vaccine doses ('secured 111 million doses') using factual language.
The segment states a risk assessment ('risk... is considered to be low') which is Q5 territory, not Q2.
The segment reports the absence of cases ('There are no active cases') using factual language.
The segment reports the absence of transmission and presence of cases ('no confirmed human-to-human transfers', 'three people... were infected') using factual language.

The segment describes the spread of the virus ('has spread across most of the U.S. states affecting primarily poultry and in recent months over 80 dairy farms') using factual language. 'Spread across' is a moderate verb.
The segment describes monitoring and securing vaccines ('continuously and actively monitoring', 'ensuring access to over 40 million doses') using factual language.
The segment describes securing vaccine doses ('in the process of securing preventative vaccine doses') using factual language.
The segment describes the intended recipients of vaccines ('intended for those most exposed') using factual language.
The segment describes the procurement process ('will be jointly procured') using factual language.
The segment describes securing vaccine doses ('secures up to 665,000 doses', 'includes an option for a further 40 million vaccines') using factual language.
The segment describes signing a contract and securing vaccines ('will sign a contract', 'secure over 40 million doses') using factual language.
The segment describes trials and uncertainties ('Veterinary trials... have started', 'there are question marks around the effectiveness') using factual language.
The segment reports a request ('called for a UK-wide compulsory housing order') and its rationale using factual language.
The segment describes trends and expert opinion ('cases dropped', 'outbreaks continued', 'experts suspecting... are now endemic', 'creating a risk') using factual language.
The segment describes a potential future situation ('situation is likely to worsen', 'increases the risk') using predictive language, not high-potency verbs or metaphors describing current impact.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'culled' to describe the outcome for the ducks.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'culled' to describe the outcome for the birds.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'culled' to describe the outcome for the birds.
The segment factually describes how avian flu is carried and spread ('is probably carried', 'spreading through') using factual language. 'Spreading' is a moderate verb.
The segment factually describes how avian flu is carried and spread ('is probably carried', 'spreading through') using factual language. 'Spreading' is a moderate verb.
The segment reports actions and statements ('did not respond to requests', 'downplayed any concerns') using factual language.
The segment assesses market conditions ('likely to have to look at imports') using factual language.

The segment mentions 'fears' (a psychological verb) and 'severely affected' (descriptive) but does not use a high-potency verb or potent metaphor to describe the disease impact itself, per the context guard for psychological verbs.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'culled' to describe the outcome for the birds.
The segment uses the moderate verb 'hit' ('has been hit particularly hard') which is excluded by the boundary guard unless coupled with scale/impact details using high-potency language.
The segment uses the superlative + negative noun phrase 'largest ever outbreak', which is listed as an Alarmist cue.
The segment describes potential consequences ('Shoppers could face shortages') and uses the moderate verb 'hit' ('understood to have been hit') which is excluded by the boundary guard.
The segment uses the moderate verb 'suffered' ('understood to have suffered multiple outbreaks') without high-potency language.
The segment reports lobbying efforts ('reported lobbying') using factual language.
The segment reports lobbying priorities ('included restrictions', 'payments for farmers', 'legislation to expand') using factual language.
The segment lists organizations without high-potency language.
The segment reports lobbying efforts ('are also lobbying') and describes a reaction ('have bristled') using factual language. 'Bristled' describes a reaction, not the disease impact.
The segment reports lobbying efforts ('reported lobbying', 'engaged Washington') using factual language.
The segment describes company activities ('working on bird flu vaccines', 'developing other therapeutics', 'have all engaged Washington') using factual language.

The segment reports lobbying efforts ('lobbying to shape the federal response') and describes consequences ('offset some of the financial toll') using factual language. 'Financial toll' is descriptive but not a high-potency verb or metaphor.
The segment states a status ('regulatory status... is unclear') using factual language.
The segment states a risk level ('risk to the general public remains low') which is Q5 territory, not Q2. It also mentions a potential 'surge' which is descriptive but not listed as high-potency.
The segment describes hiring a lobbyist and the virus's impact ('resulted in the deaths', 'spilled over') using factual language. 'Spilled over' is descriptive but not high-potency.
The quote expresses personal feeling ('pit in my stomach') about the response, not using high-potency language to describe the disease impact.
The quote states an opinion ('the big challenge is not the viruses') using factual language.
The quote states an opinion about public behaviour ('it would be very difficult to get the public to do anything') using factual language.
The segment uses the psychological verb 'worries' without a vivid intensifier or concrete scale of harm, per the context guard.
The segment uses the psychological verb 'worries' without a vivid intensifier or concrete scale of harm, per the context guard.

The segment describes potential outcomes ('have caused a wide range of illness, including severe lower respiratory tract infection and fatal outcomes') using factual/medical terms, not high-potency verbs or metaphors.
The segment states a factual observation ('wherever you go... you will find swine influenza viruses') without high-potency language.

The segment describes transmission and outcomes ('sporadically transmitted', 'have caused a wide range of illness') using factual language. 'Severe lower respiratory tract infection' and 'fatal outcomes' are factual/medical terms.
The segment describes involvement in investigations ('involved in the investigations') using factual language.
The quote states an opinion ('it's a major problem') using descriptive but not high-potency language.
The segment states an opinion about focus ('think at this point the world would be better off focusing') using factual language.
The segment states a factual observation ('None of the scientists quoted here would disagree') without high-potency language.
The quote predicts a future event ('There will be a new pandemic for sure') using factual language, not high-potency verbs or metaphors describing current impact.
The quote predicts a future event ('There will be a new pandemic for sure') using factual language, not high-potency verbs or metaphors describing current impact.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'decimated' to describe the impact on wild birds.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'decimated' to describe the impact on wild birds.
The segment uses the psychological verb 'worries' without a vivid intensifier or concrete scale of harm, per the context guard.
The segment describes a biological process ('acquired other internal genes through reassortment') using factual language.
The segment describes the cause of infections ('were caused by viruses') using factual language.
The segment states the origin of genes ('Their origin was another bird flu virus') using factual language.
The segment states a factual observation ('internal genes... were unchanging') without high-potency language.
The segment states a factual explanation ('decline in human cases is due to genetic changes') without high-potency language.
The segment describes a case ('is a rare severe case') using factual language. 'Severe case' is descriptive but not a high-potency verb or metaphor.
The segment factually describes a person's history ('who had infected ducks') without high-potency language.
The segment provides factual information about location and time without high-potency language.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'culling' (similar to slaughtered/culled in the table) to describe the action.
The segment describes trends and severity ('it wasn't uncommon', 'reports... are rare', 'often involve such mild disease') using factual language.
The segment states a factual observation ('few human infections') without high-potency language.
The quote states a factual observation ('there's just a whole lot more of it out there') using descriptive but not high-potency language.
The segment uses a psychological verb ('doesn't like') and descriptive language ('sheer geographic spread', 'increasing reports') but no high-potency verbs or metaphors describing the disease impact.
The segment factually reports findings ('Dead and sick birds infected... were reported') without high-potency language.
The segment discusses uncertainty and possibility ('one cannot say with certainty', 'seems possible') using factual language.
The quote states a factual observation ('We have been there') without high-potency language.
The segment reports infections ('infections... have been detected') using factual language.
The segment factually reports deaths ('Tigers and snow leopards... died') without using a high-potency verb or metaphor.
The segment states a factual capability ('virus has long had the capacity to infect mammals') without high-potency language.
The segment states a factual difficulty ('It's hard... to assess the significance') without high-potency language.
The segment reports infections ('reports 110 reports of mammalian infections') using factual language.
The segment is a question about possibility without high-potency language.
The segment describes a reaction ('gives flu researchers pause') using descriptive language, not a high-potency verb or metaphor describing the disease impact.
The segment discusses uncertainty and possibility ('It is not clear', 'seems possible, perhaps even probable') and uses the moderate verb 'spread' without high-potency language.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'euthanized' (similar to slaughtered/culled in the table) to describe the outcome for the animals.

The segment describes an outbreak and its effects ('outbreak, which occurred', 'saw H5N1 viruses move about', 'sickening and killing') using factual language. 'Move about' is moderate. 'Killing' is factual here (describing a number).
The segment states an opinion ('does not view... as H5N1's third act') using a metaphor ('third act') to downplay, not alarmingly frame, the situation.
The segment describes a debate and constraints ('debate... sparked continues', 'constrains... the research') using factual language.

The segment describes a struggle and concerns ('had to fight to publish', 'concerns... could provide a dangerous how-to guide') using factual language. 'Dangerous how-to guide' describes potential misuse of research, not the disease impact with a high-potency metaphor.
The segment describes research activities ('did similar work and got the same result') using factual language.
The quote states a factual historical event ('there was a pandemic threat') without high-potency language.
The quote states an opinion about risk ('that risk hasn't changed') using factual language.

The quote uses the psychological verb 'worries' without a vivid intensifier or concrete scale of harm, per the context guard. It also uses descriptive language ('change in the epidemiology', 'absolutely seeing more chances') but not high-potency verbs or metaphors.
The segment factually reports deaths ('half of those people died') without using a high-potency verb or metaphor.
The segment factually reports cases ('about 870 confirmed human cases have been detected') without high-potency language.
The segment describes historical events and outcomes ('recorded more than 250 human cases', '93 of them fatal') using factual language. 'Unsettling succession' is descriptive but not high-potency.
The segment describes the virus's movement ('moved back into wild birds, which spread it') using moderate verbs ('moved', 'spread').

The segment describes a historical event and its implication ('raised the specter of limited person-to-person spread') using descriptive language ('raised the specter') but not a high-potency verb or metaphor describing the disease impact.
The segment describes opinions and actions ('None of them like what they're seeing', 'struggled to answer') using factual language.
The segment describes an opinion ('None of them like what they're seeing now') using factual language.
The segment uses the psychological verb 'worrying' without a vivid intensifier or concrete scale of harm, per the context guard.
The segment describes a survey/interview ('STAT asked a number of experts', 'how they assess', 'how they'd describe') using factual language.
The quote states an opinion ('both of those discussions are plausible') using factual language.

The segment uses a metaphor ('multi-act play') to describe the virus's history/evolution, not its current impact. It uses moderate verbs ('spread') and descriptive language ('lengthening list', 'portends') but no high-potency verbs or metaphors describing current impact.

The segment uses a metaphor ('multi-act play') to describe the virus's history/evolution, not its current impact. It uses moderate verbs ('spread') and descriptive language ('lengthening list') but no high-potency verbs or metaphors describing current impact.
The segment states a factual event ('He retired') without high-potency language.
The segment describes a person's role and actions ('was an influenza scientist', 'was sent... to help') using factual language.
The quote expresses uncertainty ('I just don't know what it's going to do') using factual language.
The segment describes reporting findings ('were the first to report') using factual language.
The segment describes past events ('it quieted down') and expert opinions ('have a very healthy respect', 'hedging their bets') using factual language. The previous sentence contains the Q2 cue.
The segment uses the potent metaphor/idiom 'wreaking havoc' to describe the virus's impact.
The segment describes the virus's spread and host range ('has a much larger geographic footprint', 'found to infect many more species') using factual language.
The segment provides factual information and a statement ('Minks are closely related', 'animals most often used', 'important to remember') without high-potency language.
The segment provides factual information ('Minks are closely related', 'animals most often used') without high-potency language.
The segment states an assessment ('outbreak is concerning') using descriptive but not high-potency language.

The segment describes the virus's return to headlines and triggering fears ('returned to the headlines', 'triggering the latest round of fears') and potential future evolution ('inching closer') using descriptive language and psychological verbs, but no high-potency verbs or metaphors describing current impact.
The segment factually reports infections and deaths ('infected 18 people, killing six of them') without using a high-potency verb or metaphor.

The segment describes a personal feeling ('became fearful') and a potential future event ('on the verge of triggering a devastating pandemic') using descriptive language, but no high-potency verbs or metaphors describing current impact.

The segment describes outcomes ('resulted in high deaths') and risk levels ('risk... still remains low') using factual language. 'High deaths' is descriptive but not high-potency. Low risk is Q5 territory.
The segment describes potential economic consequences ('could 'contribute to poultry and egg price increases') using factual language.
The segment describes expected price changes ('expects food prices... to surge 5 percent'). 'Surge' modifying prices is treated as Neutral per the context caveat for economic trends.
The segment describes surveillance efforts ('has the strongest AI surveillance program', 'working... to actively look') using factual language.
The segment describes the outcome for birds ('resulted in the U.S. poultry industry having to kill') using factual language. 'Kill' is not high-potency here.
The segment factually reports outbreaks ('Several outbreaks have also occurred') without high-potency language.
The segment describes surveillance and testing ('are surveilling and conducting testing') using factual language.

The segment describes actions taken ('birds would 'be humanely depopulated and disposed of'', 'farm had also been quarantined') using factual/technical language. 'Depopulated' is a technical term for culling.
The segment uses the high-potency verb 'euthanized' (similar to slaughtered/culled in the table) to describe the outcome for the flock.
The segment states a factual outcome ('Birds... will not enter the food system') without high-potency language.
The segment describes actions taken ('affected areas have been quarantined', 'birds... will be depopulated') using factual/technical language. 'Affected' is moderate. 'Depopulated' is technical.
The segment describes collaboration ('working closely with state animal health officials') using factual language.

The segment describes transmission and potential outcome ('spreads easily', 'can prove deadly') using factual language. 'Spreads' is moderate. 'Can prove deadly' describes potential, not realised impact with high-potency language.
The segment factually reports confirmed cases ('cases have been confirmed') without high-potency language. 'Highly pathogenic' is a technical term.

The segment reports confirmed cases ('has confirmed cases') and a warning about potential economic impact ('officials warned that... could see Americans paying more') using factual language. The warning is about economic consequence, not the disease impact with high-potency language.
The quote states an opinion about economic feasibility ('It's not economically feasible right now') using factual language.
The segment describes challenges ('Export markets might not accept', 'costly testing would be needed') using factual language.
